sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: There might have been some likelihood of this once, but now you are old.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Old? ha! ha! he! Grutti, Grutti, dost hear him? ha! ha! he! prithee how old? how old dost think? have I not a warm moist palm? does not my pulse beat strong, and healthy?

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: The flowings of your blood, that downy chin, and these full veins, speak you — some twenty, sir.

sp.speaker: Alp:
sp.p: And of complexion sanguine, I know it by my dreams.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.l: The rosebuds now are blooming on your cheeks,
And open themselves into a crimson blush;
This hair curls up like wire, and and speaks you lusty,
Your strength is bold, and daring.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Believe it, I'm a wanton.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: Come let's to a wench then.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Hang marrying, 'tis a slavery!

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: A mere purgatory!

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: An hell to be bound to one, and she prove false, ugly, or loud, when we may enjoy our liberties, to take or leave 'em, as our stomach serves us; have the choice beauties run into our arms, and every night a fresh one.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Hey! to a wench; to a wench!Capers!now an I were King it should be treason for any subject to marry.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: Allow 'em but wenches, and 'twill be well enough.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Or to lie with a woman.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: How would you do for subjects then?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Perhaps an I had a mind to't, I'd get all my subjects myself, ha! what sayst thou to't, Grutti?

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: I say 'tis fit, you have a mind.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Bentivoglio! we are friends, come thou shalt along with us, to a wench, old trangdido, to a wench, and thou shalt so bumfiddle her.

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: Nay, good my lord, touch no more upon that string; but d'ye hear? I came to carry you to one.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Art right? art right? old boy! these physicians are notable jerkers, come, where's their rendezvous?

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: In my lodgings.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Ha? how many? — how many? — what's that there?

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: A draught to provoke.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: — Sleep.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Nay good Bentivoglio give it me, a whole one, a whole one!

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: Be moderate; you'll take the next beggar you meet else; and then the lady's expectation yonder will be frustrate.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Ha! ha! he! Super naculum! my old bully lively, my authentic don, soul of pleasure; line of life; let's to't; such a violent fit o'th sudden! A dozen calentures are an ague to't; twenty juleps will not cool one wish.

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: Let's have him to bed quickly, and heal him warm; bonum erit si sudaverit,

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Foh! his breath stinks oath university.

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: Signior 'tis not perfumed: — now will I go fetch these ladies to him; and if he have courage enough but to speak to 'em; I'll forfeit my art, and turn tooth-drawer.

div.head: Act. iii Scen. iv.
div.stage: A noise within of clashing of swords, some cry, treason! treason. Enter Ursini, and Valenzo fighting.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: My lord! —

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Villain!

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: The injury! I am not any way conscious. —

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Traitor thou liest;
Hell, and thyself the greater mischief, has
Conspired to ruin goodness. —

div.stage: Enter the guard with Piero, they seize on Valenzo. And exeunt.

div.head: Act. iii Scen. v

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Madam! you've viewed these gardens; — has not art
Sweetly conspired with nature, to make up
A pleasure of variety?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: It takes exceedingly. —

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: What does?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Pretty indeed,
To have these flowers read moral lectures to us.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Yet madam, you can find in your heart to tread
Them underfoot, scorning as much the beauty,
As the rare sense they carry.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Yes I can,
Yet straight I turn, and pluck 'em; — bind 'em up,
In one fair volume, thus —

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: And what read you, pray?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: The emblems of true virtues in each leaf,
Imprinted there, at nature's proper charges.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: What think you of this lily?

sp.speaker: Flor:
sp.p: It figures innocence.

sp.speaker: Viol:
sp.p: Wear it in your bosom.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Innocence indeed
Should be the breasts fair individual mate.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: It will become you well.

sp.speaker: Flor:
sp.l: So will this crown imperial your head,
Pray stick it there.

sp.speaker: Viol:
sp.l: I should be the envy of the court then,
'Tis a pretty flower, what think you if I carry it to the Princess?

sp.speaker: Flor:
sp.l: Fit, very apt and fit, lady, — as fit
A gift, as this were for a lord, an honeysuckle,
The amorous woodbine's offspring; it emblems love;

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: You would not have us make love?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: This mystic way has been allowed of;

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: And practised?

sp.speaker: Flor:
sp.p: Yes, and practised.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Sure I should never do't.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: No madam? why are not men creatures
As worthy courtship, as we?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Oh! but we are women!

sp.speaker: Flor:
sp.p: Oh! but we are proud.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Shall I take't on your experience?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Or your own: — hall whose voice is that?

div.stage:
Song within.
My heart is big with grief, my womb with lust,
Both fruits of my too easy trust;
Break first my heart, and it will be
To woeful me
The welcom'st, and most safe delivery.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Hence my delight! thou art turned traitor to me:
Thy strings conveyed a poison to my ears,
And they drank deeply of it; — yet forbear,
Alas it was myself, my inward grief,
Thrown from the soul in often sighs, that made
Thy sound infectious; 'tis with that as guilt,
It grows still greater as 'tis born about,
And poisons every thing should work it's cure.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Is not this Sylvio, Calantha's page?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: A lover grown? 'las pretty innocence.
How finely sorrow shows there —! That, that passion
Is well express't; now sigh, then knock the breast. Excellent.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Let's use the benefit of this shade, to hide
Ourselves, and secretly acquainted grow
With the black story of his sad mishap.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Felicia.
How has thy name, thyself, thy friend deceived thee!
That only wert acquainted with the sound
Of happiness; mocked with a false report,
Into a real misery; whose easy nature
(The greatest foe unto itself, was flattered)
Out of a virgin treasure; and then left
Rifled of all; but (What grief now is preying on)
A hapless life — yet cruel thief, thou'st left
So much of thee behind, as shall hereafter
Tell to the world a dark and gloomy tale
Of thy black perjury.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Ha! does he riddle,
Or play with grief?

sp.speaker: Viol:
sp.p: No 'tis too like a truth.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: Methinks each thing
I meet withal upbraids my fond credulity;
The soaring lark hovers aloft i'th air,
At distance from th'enchanting glass, that courts
Her to her ruin! the fearful quail
Suspects and shuns the music of the pipe
That sings her into fetters.
Only poor I am sillier than these;
Witness th'untimely swelling of this womb
Pregnant to my disgrace; — as I lay hid
In yonder thicket, the brambles gently swelled,
And hid my shame, which yet each trivial wind
But dallying with, persuaded from my covert!
And left me naked to heaven's eye; the boughs
Of the next willow clung about my head,
as if they'd knit themselves into a garland,
Which I should wear for my forsaken lover, —

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Very pretty!

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Were't not so sad.

sp.speaker: Sylv:
sp.l: O you the weak supporters of my woes,
Why d'ye fail me now at greatest need?
Bear me at least into some hollow cave
Where I may die, free from an after scorn;
And not when I am dead, be found the shame
Of our frail sex; — oh! I faint, and fall,
Just like the early branches of some tree,
Whose hasty sap shoots into early fruit,
Till the o'er laden boughs crack with the weight,
Ere yet they be full ripe —

sp.speaker: Flor:
sp.p: I am amazed, a woman!

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Some lady here o'th court, I'll lay my life on't;
Let's to the Princess and inform her of it.

div.head: Act. iii Scen. vi
div.stage: Ferrando. Ursini. (Valenzo, Piero, with guard about them.)

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: — Let me eternally perish to honour,
If their heads answer not for this foul insolence.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Though't be a sin of that portentous bulk,
That 'tstartles all the gods, and justice self
Wakes from a long dead lethargy to meet it:
Yet Kings are great as they, and spite of fate
Or rigorous laws, may triumph in their mercy.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: Away with 'em to execution;
Him, and his fellow murderer, away:
— pardon a traitor?

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Though you might urge, 'twere treason of that height,
That none but they could think of, much less act:
That murder cries for murder, blood for blood:
That he whose innocence they sacrificed
To their mad fury, was your loyal subject;
This on your marriage day — to affront Hymen.
And when your nuptial torch burned brightest, dead it
With blood, into a sickly glimmmering taper:
That they should dare assault me! — i'th' court —
One whom your goodness has been pleased to look
Into a life, and honours, placed i'th' state,
Only to interpose myself between,
And meet all dangers that are shot at you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: 'Twas a murder
Intended on our person, but that heaven —

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Was just in the prevention; true it might be so,
And were it, yet upon submission
Such faults have been remitted.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Away with 'em, I'll hear no more.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Down holy anger! —
One word, and I'm gone — you are my sovereign,
And there's divinity worn in that title,
Which I adore, and think myself as happy
In this so early doom, since you are pleased with't,
As heaven had spoke it; though not till old age,
When nature claimed it as a due! Yet sir
Be gentle to my memory; and if
At any time my crimes appear before you,
Fresh in your thought, to stain my heraldry,
The happy mention of my virtuous acts,
From some that love my dust, shall rise to plead
My innocence —; and may you never live
To curse th' untimely hand; or hour that robbed you
Of so much loyalty! — for you Ursini —
If ere your name shall fall in mention, when
I come i'th other world, expect me not
Your friend; I fear me, I shall tell sad tales
In th'ears of heaven; — farewell —

div.stage: Exeunt Val. Pier. with a guard.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Impudent traitor!

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Yet still I dare be good; and spite of all
His hate, or malice to me, thus stand up
To beg his life.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Not after so much injury?

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Yes, if Valenzo dare be sinful still
In wrongs, it shall be called my piety
To suffer.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Thou'rt all goodness; — for thy sake
We'll mix some mercy with our doom,
He that submits first to thee, has his pardon,
See justice done on th'other; this sentence
Shall stand irrevocable; —

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: This sentence stand irrevocable?
Plague to your easy nature! —
Ha! this 'tis to overact; how have I almost fooled myself, out
Of my own plots;
I were in a fine case now, if Piero
Should not accept a life on this condition.
I'll send to him — Cassio! Grutti! who waits there? —

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Ladies, pray absent yourselves a while; —
— With child? impudent whore! to what cursed lump
Have thy sins swollen thee?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: O, me miserable!

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Hence ingrate wretch! that hast abused my favours
So far, till thou hast made a sin of charity:
— ha! dost weep? —
My rare dissembler! those tears which art hath taught
To flow, carry more sinful cunning in 'em,
Than those the flattering Syrens wear upon
Their cheeks, when they court man to ruin:
Yet tell me ere you go, whom have those looks
Beguiled, and trained into your sinful arms.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: You must prepare yourself for a sad story then:

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Yes, like enough, a tale as sad, and dismal
As that of Troy, and as much truth in't too!
Quickly, dispatch, before my anger prove
Too masculine! — and be modest in'th relation.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: You'll wished untold.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Undone I do! but why
This tedious circumstance? it does involve
Your guilt.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Know then, that when I was myself
My name was —

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Felicia

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Alberto's daughter?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Yes his — that was once Alberto
Durazzo's far-famed marquess; till
His cruel master seized on's life, and honours,
At his return from Sicily i'th first wars;
Where he received a fatal overthrow.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: He was in action bold, and valiant!
However fortune wrought him this disgrace;

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Here! here began my misery.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Proceed, trust me I now begin to pity thee.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Then let me die without your farther knowledge
Of my mishap; 'twill be injurious
Unto my ashes, and disturb their quiet;
I know it will;

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Nay, prithee tell me, come, and I'll weep with thee.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: You'll have cause enough ere I've done;
Therefore don't hear't;

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Is there ought in't concerns me?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Too much

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Nay, than I must, and will have all the story,
Or think thee a foul prostitute.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: 'Tis thus then!
— yet don't believe me, say that I was mad,
Distracted with my sorrows, that my words
Fell so uneven from me, you mistook
The sense; say any thing. —

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Come, come, I know thou wilt tell truth!

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Or may I never find peace hereafter!

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: How I fear
whether this story tends?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: The King madam.
Ferrando; — (Seize me courteous death,
Or I shall poison all her joys;)

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Ha! what of him?
Be sudden, or, I swear by my just anger,
I'll straight rip up the cradle of thy lust,
The den where all thy loose adulteries
Were acted; search each corner of thy womb.
That keeps a record of thy villainies!

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Ferrando was the author of my fall:

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: More lying than that evil genius
That wrought the first man's fall!

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Ferrando! o! o! (Swoons)

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Thou rebel passion jealousy! what meanest thou
To tumult in my breast? — ha! yet why not?
Why may not he be false?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Oh! o! o!

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: 'Tis so! — Felicia! — she's gone, she's gone!
Help there, Florinda! Violetta! Ladies!
So — she begins to breathe; — look up Felicia!

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Where am I?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Here, — a medal? this confirms it;
sp.stage: Finds a medall about her neck with the picture of Fer: and Fel. in it
sp.l: Ferrando and Felicia!

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Ha! the Princess!
Beshrew me but I've had a fearful dream!
I hope was but a dream;

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: No; I know all,
Ferrando's false, as stained with sin, and perjury
As howling-ghosts.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Good madame don't affright me;
Your fancy's dark and gloomy.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Yes all hell
Is there at work contriving a revenge;

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Revenge? for whom?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: No matter whom; — but tell me
How, and with what false oaths, he won thee first
to his loose sheets.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: I'll tell you; but you first
Shall promise me, to bread no other way
To your revenge and mine, than I shall lead you in.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I do:
Let's sir, and hear it all.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Whilst yet Alberto lived
As great in favour as in blood, the glory
O'th court of Naples, honoured with daily visits
From his prince; was my unhappy destiny,
(Fool that I was to be so credulous!)
To receive many favours from Ferrando;
Which I interpreted i'th way of love;
Meanwhile , this match was treated of between
Him, and yourself; your father (Sicily's King)
After your plighted troths, and formal ceremonies
Used betwixt prince, and prince, would break it off,
Which caused a sudden war upon his country;
In which expedition Alberto
Was sent chief general: the King being forced
Now to withdraw his public visits, employed
Ursini in the business; gets access
Privately to me i'th might, and that too
Always i'th dark, lest happily he might
Be known to any of my servants; briefly
After his many oaths, and protestations
Of his fair meaning, I at last consented
To let him steal the fruit, he durst not own:
When ere I urged, he was engaged to you,
He answered, that was but a trick of state,
A fair pretence to colour his design;
And make't seem glorious, in the eye o'th world;
That he warred for a kingdom, not a Queen;
Only entreated me, that I'd be silent,
And not so much as in a sign betray
To'th day, what only night was conscious of.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: You condescended?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Willingly.
My father i'th meanwhile returns defeated,
For which the King led on by passion, seized
His life and honours, these conferred on his
Now favourite Ursini: the fleet re enforced,
He himself the second time in person
Went general of the forces, conquered Sicily,
And slew your father on Messina's plains,
Last brought you away captive.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: But how cam'st thou to court in Sicily?
Thou toldest another story then:

sp.speaker: Syl:
sp.l: For that
I crave your pardon, 'twas all the untruths
My life has ere been charged with; but 'twas thus:
Led partly by a jealous fear, to see
What he intended; partly to find out
My brother Frederico, who was left there
Commander in Mazara, which was taken
In the first expedition, in this disguise,
'Mongst others whom desire of fame, or profit
Led to your shore, I crossed the seas; but failing
In quest of him I sought, I came to court,
Where since I have remained.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: But why Felicia
Didst not disclose thyself before this time,
Now things are grown so bad?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: When first I saw
Your person, and how mutually you loved,
Knowing how far I was beneath your worth,
So dear I held you both, that I determined
For ever to be lost to memory;
And serve you thus in this disguise: which I
Had done, but that this hapless chance
Betrayed me to your knowledge.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Alas! thy piety has undone us both!

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: 'Twas my too cruel destinies!

sp.speaker: Cal,
sp.l: Methinks we two now seem to be set copies
of griefs, to which wronged virgins will repair,
To take out patterns by.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Our wrongs and sorrows
Have made us just so like to one another,
That each seems the others counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: We'll sit, and descant on our miseries,
Count the extent of each, proportion tears,
And sighs unto them.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Here's that doth surmount,
Shall borrow grief of tother.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Has robbed me of a father cruel tyrant,

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Has robbed me of a father cruel tyrant,

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: Bereaved me of my friends, and loving subjects,

sp.speaker: Syl:
sp.p: Bereaved me of my brother, and my friends.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: Ta'e away all my honours, and my dower.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Taken my virgin honour, all my dower.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: Has mocked me with the title of a Queen.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Has mocked me with the title of a Queen.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: — But I am lost in passion.

sp.speaker: Sylv:
sp.p: And I am lost in passion.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: Felicia come, and as our wrongs are equal,
So let our revenge be; we'll hand in hand
Assault this tyrant; and in bloody characters
Print on his body the story of our sufferings:

sp.speaker: Syl:
sp.p: Yet this cannot cure our grief.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: What though, wronged innocence?
In death it will entitle us to honours;
And though our bodies moulder to corruption,
Our better part shall survive fame; our names,
Free from decay, shall swell up numerous volumes;
Whilst our sad legends shall be made a pillow,
To every sleeping virgin.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: O yet for my sake have some pity on him,
And for that part of him, that's cradled here,
Alas he may live to make us fair amends.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: For thy sake I could spare him, but my wrongs
Sit heavy here, and urge me to revenge.

sp.speaker: Syl:
sp.l: But say L've thought a way, how we may yet
Be both restored to happiness, would you not
Accept, and follow't?

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: Speak it (Gentle soul.)

sp.speaker: Syl:
sp.l: As yet (You know) your virgin treasure stands
Free from his ruder touch: those ceremonies,
Which linked you in one hymeneal knot,
Religion will make void, the precontract
Betwixt him and me being known, so that you then,
On this part are free from him; enjoy him thus
You cannot, neither would you (I suppose)
After these wrongs, (If you might be permitted:)
What hinders then, but that I take your place
This night? and show him, to what height his perjury
Has wrought our wrongs, whilst you in some disguise
May quit the court, and ere next sun appear,
From hence towards France, to whom you are allied
In blood, and wrongs. —

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: Content, — I'll in, and haste me to be gone,
To go there is some hope.

sp.speaker: Syl:
sp.p: To stay there's none.

div.head: Scen. i.
div.stage: Piero. Cassio. as in the prison.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.p: — To me this?

sp.speaker: Cass:
sp.l: Out of particular respect
He stood engaged to repay your merits.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.l: Dare you
Promise so much for's lordship?

sp.speaker: Cass:
sp.l: The contents
Of that will speak, how much he tenders goodness
In every noble breast.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.l: No doubt sir, but
You are familiar with the sense it carries,
And can inform me, better than the dark character.

sp.speaker: Cass:
sp.l: 'Tis that you'd be pleased t'accept
A life, for which to's piety you shall owe,
Only a fair acknowledgement.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.l: Wondrous good!
'Tis a becoming charity this, and he
Wears it amongst the chiefest of his virtues.

sp.speaker: Cass:
sp.l: Sir, it must needs be eminent in's lordship,
Since exercised upon so noble a subject
As yourself

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.l: But stay? — now I think on't,
This is a benefit of that nature, it seldom comes
Alone, are there not honours too? preferments
That wait upon this gift? speak, shall I be
His lordship's creature?

sp.speaker: Cass:
sp.p: He's passionately yours.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.l: Are we not for design? — ba, what dark trick
Is there i'th state, that doth imply danger
Enough for us to manage, doth he think
Us fit to temper poisons, or use the benefit
O'th night to seize on his state-rivals, are we
Potent enough for faction, or intended
Intelligencer to some foreign prince?

sp.speaker: Cass:
sp.p: What mean you?

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Engagements of this nature urge a return
Of thanks proportionable to themselves,
And what we have of such rich values,
I cannot tell, lest t'be our souls forfeited
To'th next occasion his lordship has to use 'em.

sp.speaker: Cass:
sp.l: This is strange language sir, my understanding
Has not yet arrived at what it means.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.l: Go home and study it then: — and d'ye hear,
Entreat my lord, t'employ his favours to
Some further profit, he'll scarce be gainer by 'em else.

sp.speaker: Cass:
sp.p: I shall acquaint him with your humour.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.p: Do maggot, wriggle, wriggle, do: —

div.head: Act. iv. scen. ii.
div.stage: To Piero, Charintha; (Valenzo behind the hangings.)

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Piero.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Madam! I am all joy, life, honours,
Preferment, and what not?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Then I'm undone!
Piero! didst not promise me to stand
The utmost of's temptations? didst thou boast
Thy virtuous strength, and fallest at the first onset?

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.p: Life madam is sweet.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: If hitherto
It hath been so, hereafter 'twill be all
Bitterness, thou hast betrayed thy friend to death;
The thought of which will sour all thy content,
Make thy best pleasures relish worse than gall.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Life, with the worst that can befall us, is
A good exchange for death; but here are honours
Annexed to't lady! I shall be great in favour.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Thou wilt grow big in sin too! thou must barter
Thy virtue for preferment; which being gone,
At best thou'lt be but painted ruins,
A glorious misery; thou must owe life
To him, that will infect and kill thy soul.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Yet you would be content, Valenzo should
Accept a life, on this condition.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Yet he may live, and still be virtuous.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.p: Why? so may I.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Yet he's thy friend.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.p: Am not I his too?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: 'Twill be a glory to thee after death
That thou wert friendships martyr, a title
Will sit upon thy tomb, richer than all
Thy heraldry; more lasting than thy marble.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: To show how far, I can prefer him to
Myself, I am content this honour should be his.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.l: False to thy friend, and virtue! that only cam'st
To mock calamity, and midst our wrongs
Remain our greatest in jury.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Mistake me not,
I only did prepare you for a joy,
Which now you're ripe for: — know then, 't returned
Him scorn for all his flattering promises;
And stood resolved t'incounter with his fury,
Made hot by my disdain.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.p: Miracle of friendship.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Since 'tis decreed that one of us must fall,
And only one, my death shall free us both
From the law's rigour, enjoy your best Valenzo,
Enjoy him long, may you (A happy pair)
Grow like two neighbouring roses on one stalk,
Partaking mutually each others sweets;
Whence no rude hand approach to ravish you,
But when you are full blown, and ripe for heaven,
May you fall gently both into one grave,
There lie entombed in your own odours.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Piero, thou goest
To heaven, to be the envy of the saints;
For when thou comest where those blessed troops reside,
No man shall ere direct a vow, or prayer,
But unto thee! — Valenzo take thy friend,(Val: enters)
Take him unto thy bosom, he has so much
Of heaven in him, I fear he can scarce die.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.l: Is it your fear, madam? can he deserve less in
Your fair opinion, than to be thought immortal?
That death at length should boast a victory
O'er so much goodness. — methinks (Piero)
Thou shouldst for ever stand a rich example,
To all mankind, who in thy fall will sicken,
And die to virtue; enjoy the happiness
Of thine own fate; I will not rob thee of
One precious minute; live till time has poured
A reverend snow upon thy head. —

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.p: But justice must be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.p: I'll bow myself beneath the stroke.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.l: To slay
The innocent, is not to expiate,
But make a crime, preserve thyself entire
To thy Charintha, King, and country.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.l: What!
And betray my friend to death?

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: To what
I have deserved.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.l: Was thy too forward zeal, and a ripe spirit.
That spurred thee on to action, thou didst it for
Thy friend, for me, and had not justice been
Wronged in't, the honour had been mine, why not
The shame?

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.p: You must not, shall not die.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.l: No more!
'Twill prove a breach of friendship else, I must not,
Shall not die: my honour suffers double,
Thou wouldst foil me both in love, and valour.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.p: Pity these tears.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.l: Or in thy ruin I
Am lost.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.l: Justice requires but one, her fate
Is so involved in yours, you cannot fall,
But in it she must find a certain death;
Think then, how can you satisfy the law?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Far easier than you, in whose sad loss
The whole world suffers, and in thy unripe fall
Loses all goodness.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.l: Stint this pious strife,
I have been too much woman, and betrayed
My name to infamy, in this tame passion:
Possess me a just anger, a spirit great
And noble as my birth; that I may shake,
And rouse this sleepy prince, from his dull lethargy;
Who's wholly lost, in the bewitching flatteries
of that bad man; — alas this is a danger
Too potent for your stars to free you from;
Henceforth I'll be your destinies: for since
This calm brings nothing but a certain fall,
A storm shall either save, or ruin all.

div.head: Act. iv. scen. iii.
div.stage: A table is set forth; taper, pen, ink, etc.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Contemn our pardon.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Return your favours too
With so much scorn.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: Better they'd played with lightning,
Or hugged a thunderbolt.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Justice is slow
Of pace, and if not led by fury,
Seldom o'ertakes the crime, let your return
Of punishment be quick, and active, delay is worse
Than pity, and more dangerous: Valenzo
Is popular, and who knows, but he had rather,
Owe his life to the people's mutiny, than your pardon,
And therefore slighted it.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: O the state of princes!
How far are we from that security,
We dreamt of in th'expectance of our crown?
Were foreign dangers nothing, yet we nourish
Our ruin in our bosom: Valenzo is a traitor,
So is Piero too; and who is not in this age?
It is unsafe not to suspect ourself.
To torture with 'em; be noble in thy justice: —
Here draw a warrant for their execution; —
We'll sign't with our own signer; — hence pity,
Post from our breast; we banish thee our bosom
Thou'rt a disease bred there to ruin majesty:Ursini preparing to write.
And sink us below our subjects' scorn. —

sp.speaker: Charintha?
sp.l: Our princely cousin, welcome to court; thou hast
been too long absent, (I must chide thee for't,)
And envied us the boast of virtue.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.p: Virtue!

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Some malicious devil now, or other,
Has enticed her from her beads;
To undo me, and my plots, she carries anger
In her brow: — this I must mitigate, or I am
Lost. —

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: Thou art so eager after heaven,
Thou wilt o'er-buy thy happiness.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.p: Never fear't sir.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: But thy devotion's seasoned with so much charity,
Thou pilest a stock of merit up for us
At court.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.p: I believe y'had need on't.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: As long as we live here we shall; —

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.p: So wicked!

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: Ha! what frowne's that, whence these clouds, Charintha?
So rises the blushing morn, as thou wert wont
To smile, when thou appearedst, we owe
Our day unto thy eyes; and if thou think'st
Thy beauty's worn too cheap, we'll become tributaries
To thee for light; chase hence this sullen darkness,
Thy absence has already made too long
A night.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.p: No sir; 'twas your black deeds ▪

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: How's this?
D'ye know me, who I am?

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.p: Not well.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Your King.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.l: A tyrant
Of big, and grorious impieties,
A regal monster, the true head of that
Beast you rule, the multitude: more cruel
Than enraged lions, or robbed bears; who both
Will spare the innocent, and humble.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Look to'th lady there, sure she's distracted.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.p: My wrongs indeed would make me so.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: What wrongs? whence? or from whom?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Raise not my anger higher with your scorn; —

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: By all that's. —

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Or if't be ignorance of my sufferings,
It but betrays your want of reason, and
How far you're lost to man, by your fond dotage.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Grow more particular, or wonder ruins me.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Good God! I've suffered so long, till patience
Grew my greatest crime. —

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Now, now the storm is coming this way,
But I'm prepared to meet it.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Whence? or from whom?
Ask this good man how often he has mourned
Over the ruins of my fame? how often
His ears have met with the report of my
Disgrace? how I was noised a strumpet? when
Each talking thing at court, might freely act
A rape upon my virtue, till I was left
All a whole stain, black as the front of perjured
Sinners? while you, (As if I'd been a trifle
Cast from your blood, and kindred, or some dark thing,
Whose actions were so fowly bad.
That report bettered 'em in the expression:)
Could sit as silent as the night; as calm
As seas, when the winds sleep; yet at last be just;
And say, how have I appeared to you, or him,
That calumny has thus been privileged,
To violate my honour?

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Madam,
I have always spoke you, chastities best example.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Innocence itself is not so white.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Yet he that would confirm this with his sword,
Must meet, with prisons, wracks, and tortures,
As a reward of so much virtue!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Sweetest Princess! —

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.l: And ere he die, must suffer in's honour,
Be proclaimed traitor to the state:

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Ursini, thou hast abused our trust.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: My lord. —

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.l: Too weak pretence, for your ingratitude
To so large merit; Naples calls him
Her chief preserver; he brought home victory,
By his own arm achieved, when the proud foe,
Threatened your kingdom with a fatal downfall.
He, to whose arm you owe your life, your crown,
To whom in war, you'd sooner fly for help
Then to the altar; now in peace must have
His temples robbed; his garlands from his brow
Transplanted. to adorn this useless statua.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Madam, I have not so appeared in managing these affairs of yours.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Would thou hadst,
Or somewhat that carries less resemblance
Of man: o thou art bravely wicked.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: I have not used the art to boast the virtue
Of mine own actions; yet heaven knows
They were all good, and aimed at ends as honourable
As your desires.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ursini leave, till there is hope of pardon,
This impudence in sin,
Bids a defiance to all mercy; did we not,
At your persuasion, give order for Valenzo's
Quick dispatch?

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: howe'er I seemed (Great sir) to run down with the stream of your violent passion, yet my intents still bore up against it; witness this paper.
sp.stage: Deliver's a paper to Ferrando, who reads it.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Ha! what's here a pardon?

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Which you had sealed ere this, had not this lady here interrupted it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Your passion would not have permitted you,
To have o'er viewed what you consented too;
This I knew, as likewise how dangerous it
would have been to the state, if he had fallen.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: Again my own Ursini: —
Charintha, pardon our errors, we will deserve it,
By the future love, and honours we will throw
On our Valenzo, — here take my signer
Fetch 'em to court.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.p: You are noble.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Ursini wait on her to the castle.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: You honour me.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: O how near were we destruction.
Reason sit still enthroned in thine own state,
'Tis passion only ruins Kings, not fate.

div.head: Act. iv. scen iv.
div.stage: Bentivoglio. Alphonso. Grutti. Cassio. Violetta. Florinda.

sp.speaker: Bent:
sp.p: Hold up, hold up sir, the ladies are coming this way, — for shame, — God's me, they're here; why d'ye tremble so sir?

sp.speaker: Alph:
sp.p: A violent fit o'th ague; o! o! o! have me to bed gently, gently, or I shall scatter all my limbs;

sp.speaker: Bent:
sp.p: Discredited for ever, (Here take this staff sir) — have I boasted your strength to them? — fortified you for th'encounter, and you fail me thus? — undone, undone!

sp.speaker: Alph:
sp.p: Oh! o! o! for half a dozen of night caps.

sp.speaker: Bent:
sp.p: Here sir, on with 'em; they're somewhat dirty, they'll keep you the warmer; — now shall I be called mountebank; quacksalver, pisspot-peeper: and all the ugly mangy names can be invented. — come in, come in. —

sp.speaker: Grut:
sp.p: 'Twill be a scene of modest mirth, ladies.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: The physician has cooled him.

sp.speaker: Bent:
sp.p: Why sir, you won't disgrace me? go towards 'em.

sp.speaker: Alph:
sp.p: Some fire, some fire; — cold, cold, cold, cold.

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: Here, here, on with my gown: — this cap, so, so.

sp.speaker: Grut:
sp.p: Ladies, we'll take leave to be bold here to vex him.

sp.speaker: Viol:
sp.p: How d'ye my lord?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: We are come here to await your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: The very thought on't has cast him into a cold sweat.

sp.speaker: Alph:
sp.p: Oh! o!

sp.speaker: Cass:
sp.p: Now for fifty virgins.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: A monopoly of women.

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: Hey, for a wench, for a wench, to bumfiddle now; ah! ha!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Oh! ho! o!

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: D'ye remember you'd play the fool in my gown, and cap excellently.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Well said doctor.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: To him doctor.

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: Then a noise of musicians would do rarely.

sp.speaker: Cass:
sp.p: Look he's nodding.

sp.speaker: Viol:
sp.p: My lord you intend no abuse to us?

sp.speaker: Flor:
sp.p: Make us hazard our credits for nothing?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: More clothes; — why ho there, on my feet I say.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: He's dreaming.

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: Fast, fast asleep , so, so, this charm lasts till midnight, and then he wakes.

sp.speaker: Grut:
sp.p: 'Twill be good sport to see him then —

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: Dance up and down the court like the ghost of old Hippocrates.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: You must not expose him to the public view.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: Mr. doctor you're sufficiently revenged, this is enough for you to boast on when you come i'th university.

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: This, and the rare cures I've done upon you two shall be my theme. — good night. — ladies I'm your servant. — my doughty placket-hunter lie thee there, and e'en awake when thy stomach serves thee; tomorrow morning I'm for Padua. —

sp.speaker: Zisc.
sp.l: The night comes on apace, straight every thing
Will be as black as I, and alike terrible,
Nay outdo me too: each leaf that stirs
affrights the fearful, makes the guilty tremble,
And yet this night, what is it but a shadow?
Yet I am less than that, for I do less:
I that have purposed so much, act nothing!
Horror! could but my thoughts be seen, they'd own
Murders, more than the basilisk could commit,
Were he all eye, more than revenge has acted,
Or than the trivial spite of plague, and war
Produce, in their full heat. — Ursini be speedy
Or I'll outrun design. —

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Zisco.

sp.speaker: Zisc.
sp.p: My lord.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: The hours are favourable
And have brought opportunity along with 'em,
We must resolve for action.

sp.speaker: Zis.
sp.p: I'm prepared.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: But Zisco, art thou sure Felicia was. —

sp.speaker: Zis.
sp.l: Sure? puh! would you know? I myself
Am the Moor he caused to ravish her.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: And canst thou do't again?

sp.speaker: Zis.
sp.p: Bravely.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: This night than thou shalt — ravish his mistress,
Calantha! this night! I've prepared all things ready
For thy conveyance into her chamber — thou wilt do't

sp.speaker: Zis.
sp.p: Resolved.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: And kill her too?

sp.speaker: Zisc.
sp.p: An she were my mother.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Obscure yourself a while. — how now?

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.l: My lord, the French have kept their word,
And unespied have stolen from Genoa,
Entered our haven, and this night have set
Upon our fleet, the bold Sicilians too
I'th town are up in arms.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: There spoke my genius.

sp.speaker: Cass:
sp.l: My lord! the city's in a mutiny,
The court in wild distraction.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Well, beyond my hopes: excellent well; Grutti, Cassio, be near us, we must use your help tonight .

sp.speaker: Cass:
sp.l: Valenzo plays from the castle with his canons,
And strikes both parties without distinction:
he's now marching up with a well ordered troop,
'Tis thought he had intelligence of your intents.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: O my fate! that man undoes me.
Thus early sins are blasted in the bud,
There is no safety but in being good.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.l: — 'tis late.
Each man retire to his quarter: captains,
We entertain your merit with a serious welcome.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: Our deserts, my lord,
Are so slender, that were't not to prejudice
Your judgement, we would blush to own any.

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.p: Hang this flattery, merit quotha? is't such a piece of merit to cut a score or two of throats; knock down an hundred o'th city herd? A gallant could do so much for's cockatrice.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.p: The King shall give you each particular thinks: he owes you both a trophy,

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: His acknowledgement
Of our duty, would raise our pride to sin,
We should forget to let heaven share i'th victory.

sp.speaker: Cont:
sp.p: Victories, by Mars's crest it deserves not to come i'th chronicle, though Hollinshead or hall, those voluminous foreigners should write our annals, 'twill never make us justle in among the Caesars, or own a name i'th list o'th worthies.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No Contareno, we will not have thee painted in vile ugly colours, and clapped upon chimneys, thou shalt be cut —

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.p: In brass? mine would make an excellent brazen face?

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.l: In Parian marble, we'll rob the quarries
To rear thee up a glorious monument.

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.p: A glorious loam to set lazy spiders a work in, an office for birds to mute in, if these be your glorious monuments for men of arms, I'll e'en live to sin out my merit (As you call it) then when I die, the world and I will shake hands, and cry quit of all sides.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
He that should hear thee talk thus, and not know
thee well, would doubt thy valour.

sp.speaker: Cont:
sp.p: Hercules! an he did he should try it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Twere punishment enough.
Gonçales — I gratulate thy naval victory;
France will have cause hereafter to mention thee in sad story,
Thou givest them but a churlish salutation.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Such as they deserved,
It seems they came rather to steal than fight,
They were as ill prepared, as they had meant
To bear our empty hulks away unquestioned;
For soon as they perceived we descried 'em,
Pale, as the lilies in their trembling flags,
They turned their sails, and fled; we made after 'em,
With swift winged lightning from our canon's mouth,
Which sunk and fired 'em all, ere they could quit
The channel, or gain the wider ocean;

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Believe me, noble soldier, thou art dear
To fame; as old in victory, as in years,
Yet still thou toil'st t'undo thyself, and benefit
Thy ingrateful soil, which never will be able
To requite thy meanest service.

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.l: Yet you for the same cause, i'th pride of youth,
Opposed yourself betwixt the state and danger,
When their sick hopes, were as their fortunes, desperate;
Reduced a kingdom to your sway, in whose
Rich spoils, your gawdy soldier triumphs;
Whilst boasting of their rifled plumes, they drink
Healths to victory; yet those so moderate,
Their bowls increase their fury, not their surfeits.

sp.speaker: Cont:
sp.p: How these tall men o'th sword claw one another?

sp.speaker: Gal:
sp.p: They have an itch of pride runs through 'em.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The heroes, when thou comest into Elysium,
To give thee place, shall shift their blessed mansions.

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.p: And load thee with their laurels.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: How my fears betray me! shunning
one toil, I run into another.

sp.speaker: Cont:
sp.p: Che va la?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: O me! I'm surprised.

sp.speaker: Cont:
sp.p: Spirit of valour thou'rt my prisoner.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Ha! whom have you there?

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: (Valenzo! my voice betrays me.)

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.l: A young Sicilian, shall I draw my steel,
And give him a gentle stroke?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Lend me my sword — and be thou what thou wilt I dare thee to thy worst.

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.p: Bravely spoke, — set forward then. —

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Traitor! the Princess! Calantha!

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.l: All the better; she's skilful at her weapon,
We'll but exchange a thrust in sport.

sp.speaker: Gal. and Gon.
sp.p: Ha! what means this flight?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Dare none of you fight?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Dear lady, not with you.

sp.speaker: Cal,
sp.l: Then you are cowards, they speak you so i'th city,
And I came out thus purposely to try you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: If you please, you shall quickly see that,
Command us sheathe our swords in one another's
Bosoms — we'll fly like lightning to execute your
Commands; — you're our Princess.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: No, I'm your prince's murderess.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: I've killed your King: will none
Dispatch me yet?

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.p: Sure she's distracted.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.l: We must disarm you lady; — 'tis a duty to our prince
Was never till now unwillingly performed!
You must back to'th court, whither we'll wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: Villains, cowards,

sp.speaker: Gal:
sp.p: The Princess! what made she abroad so late?

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.p: Did she not say that she had killed the King too?

sp.speaker: Gal:
sp.p: Come let's walk the round; things are yet unsettled.

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.p: 'Tis so dark now, an the devil should lie perdieu I should go near to stumble on's horns.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Too much of this sad story, o these men
how are they degenerate from the goodness
Of their creation! they have been always false —

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Silly as we are,
We know it; their vows and oaths are traitors
To us, and yet we hug them, let them into our bosoms,
Into our hearts, till they undo us?

sp.speaker: Flor:
sp.l: But madam, why d'ye desire us to leave you?
Fear you not his fury, what it may prompt him too,
When he shall see you are not his Calantha.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: He never was acquainted with that passion,
He's violent in nothing, — but in love.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: And yet he may dissemble that too
As well as his vows.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Should he? were his hand
Lift up to strike me, I can charm it there!
Who can look on a lady's bent knees,
Wet cheeks, swollen eyes, hear her sighs, her prayers,
And yet be cruel: if there be one that can,
That one is not Ferrando; his bosom is
Passable to every groan; it strikes his heart:
He would tell me (When he was absent)
If I sigh't, or wept, for then he said
He wept and sighed by sympathy.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Yet now he loves you not.

sp.speaker: Fel:
sp.l: Can he not love himself? here, here I bear him,
Himself in a less model, this I'll show him,
If he mistrust 'tis none of his; let him
But rip me up, there he shall see each limb
As like to his, as his one hand, one eye,
One cheek is like the other: besides there lies
Folded by his own name, he told me he
Would call it so, (Ferrando,) and lest I
Should chance forget, I wrote it in my heart,
There he will find it.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Good lady!

sp.speaker: Viol:
sp.p: 'Tis a sad nuptial night, this,

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: I'll tell him too how he
Would grieve if I were dead, go hanging down
his head, vailing his eyes from heaven, ashamed
To look up to the place, where his Felicia is:
Or poring on the ground, as he would find
Where my neglected ashes lay a sport
To th' winds; where some rude blast might blow me up
Into his eyes, and then he'd weep to find,
Me there; weep till the fretting brine had burned
His eyeballs out.
He told me of his dreams, what pleasure he
Had to find me in 'em: alas they will
Be terrible now: I shall affright him, appear
A thin pale ghost, make him start out in his sleep;
(Alas! I will not) yet he'll dream he heard me.
Cry out, Ferrando! revenge upon Ferrando:
This cannot choose but startle him. —

sp.speaker: Viol:
sp.p: Heaven grant it may.

sp.speaker: Flor:
sp.l: Madam all joy that we can hope, or wish,
Be with you.

sp.speaker: Fer: —
sp.l: I'll go alone into the bedchamber.
There expect him, — pray leave me.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Good night, I hear him coming.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Our navy victor.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: The city quiet too I those clouds
Which threatened ruin to your kingdom, all
Blown o'er; the sky serene and calm, as if
It laughed at your vain fears; the lamps of heaven
That now seemed all blown out, are trimmed a new
And brighter shine, to lead you to Elysium.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: To heaven, Elyzium's poor to what we shall
Enjoy tonight .

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: The land of some dull villager
Or doughty poets dreams.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: The birth of fancy,
A thin, fantastic, airy paradise;
With which they flatter their weak hopes, but mine
Is known to sense; we gather odours there; wealthy
In their native sweetness, flowers of a hue
as bright as lasting, roses and lilies
Blown from their stalks, meet here, and dwell upon
Her cheeks, as if there only they were privileged
To enjoy an everlasting spring.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Let your
Imaginations seed even to a surfeit, your senses
Are too too weak, and narrow t'entertain
The bounteous flowing of her pleasures:
You'll let so much pass by unknown,
As if you took but tribute of her blessings:
When the whole stock is yours.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: We'll be her Mars, and meet her in soft skirmish,
In amorous duel, where we'll softly yield
And let her win: (To raise her to the pride
Of a new victory, as much upon ourselves
As we have done upon her country,
Then shall she bind us gently in her hair
Fetters for captive lovers, and in scorn
Of our trim youth, and temperate blood, when we
Begin to faint within her arms, shall then
Supply us with new strength from her own eyes;
Whence she will dart a soul at every glance
Rich as herself, and the blessed smiles 'tis made of;
Create an active flame within our breast
Able to give old statua's life and motion,
Make their stiff marble feet supple as the joints
Of love: — o I'm lost! my Venus
Come; lead to my Venus.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Your Cynthia, — your moon
sp.stage: Curtain drawn, Feticia discovered lying upon a bed, Zisco ▪ as having ravished, and then slain her.
sp.l: With a man in her — there there's
Your way, why move you not?
How you stand.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: Ursini, ha! seest thou that black thing there?
That ugly fiend, I'll out stare thee, devil.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Where are you sir?

sp.speaker: Zis:
sp.p: 'Tis done.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: Ravished! Calantha's ravished — o torment!
Grim fury post to hell.

sp.speaker: Zis:
sp.l: Pardon me sir,
I've a little business to dispatch first —
This for Felicia, thus Alberto fell.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: O I'm wounded.

sp.speaker: Zis:
sp.p: Ha! d'ye know me prince?

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Frederico! just heavens.

sp.speaker: Zis.
sp.l: Stay your hand — be innocent in your revenge,
Let me bear all the guilt.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Couldst thou think, dull prince, that heaven so
Doted on thy royalty, thy crown, thy sceptre,
Or regal pall could bear thee out in sin?
Or the weak shine of trivial state dazzle
Their eyes that look upon the blessed sun!
Couldst thou flatter thyself into such a security,
That vengeance would not find thee out?
When thou hadst forfeited thy luxurious palate
With all the dainties of Felicia's body
Thirsted her blood, quaffed off whole bowls of it,
Till thou were't drunk, and wild with fury
Of thy intemperate draughts — am not I a rare villain now?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Mad, stark mad, besides himself,
Sure this is but a dream, and I asleep.

sp.speaker: Zis:
sp.p: Thus, thus I'll wake you: —

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: O my blood scalds, h'has shot wild fire into my heart,
Ah traitor, thy steel is poisoned.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Frederico, let me embrace thee:
Now our revenge is perfect.
sp.stage: A noise within. Enter fighting, Valenzo, Grutti, Gonçales, Cassio, Calantha.

sp.speaker: Grut:
sp.p: Your passage lies this way.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: Through us.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.p: Treason, treason, raise the court.

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.p: Break open the doors.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: We are betrayed.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.p: Villain I greet thy heart.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: Where tends your business?

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.p: Slave to hell, and thou shalt carry't thither.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Fire, fire, the poison boils my entrails.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.p: The prince wounded!

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.p: Where are the traitors?

sp.speaker: Zis:
sp.p: Here I am his murderer.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.p: Frederico.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Valenzo, I am o'ercome. —

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p:
New miracles, Calantha, my best my dearest love: — o I am sick, stand off Calantha, my breath's so hot, 'twill singe thee else; and lick thy beauties up, like nimble flames;
but dost thou live?

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: To curse thee false and perjured.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: The spheres are out of tune; nature's distraught;
The orbs celestial have turned round so long
That they are giddy: the stars are in a mutiny,
The intelligences are altogether by'th ears.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: Heaven! I bless your justice:
Stern tyrant! that triumphest o'er the memory
Of my father, mockest me with love,
Till like a fool I doted on my fetters,
'Cause they were golden ones, that thus
Thy devilish art might make my soul a captive,
With my body.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Enigmatical.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: Yet then a lady mourned thy perjured vows.
Whom thou betrayd'st to loose adultery.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Thy speech, Calantha, is darker than an oracle.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: Truer it is, and dar'st thou yet dissemble it?
'Tis a truth precious to time, who will preserv't
To blast thy memory, and derive a stain
On all thy successors.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: How? or when arrived this your knowledge madam?

sp.speaker: Zis.
sp.p: How? or when arrived this your knowledge madam?

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: Felicia told me all herself
Confirmed it by religious oaths; besides
This medal which she gave me from her neck,
A pledge of his broke faith, with the sad fruits
Of his sate lust, within her womb.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: She's a black whore: she lies; believe her not.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Thou wilt be damned:

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: So may I; and howl eternally
In those blue flames the devils bathe in,
If ever my vows were made to any other
Than thee; and those, as spotless as thy soul. —

sp.speaker: Urs:
sp.p: But whom have we here?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Felicia! Sad lady she entreated
This night's exchange of place; that she might show him
What an untimely mother he had made her,
And this 'twas caused my flight,

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Felicia!

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: Ha! murdered.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: My love.

sp.speaker: Zis.
sp.l: My sister! ravished:
And murdered by! me, incestuous villain!

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Didst thou not tell me that Ferrando ravished her,
And cast her to his slaves, a prey to their
Bold appetites and furies.

sp.speaker: Zis.
sp.l: To incense you the more against him; I told you
What I only did imagine, because at my return
From Sicily, report whispered her lost,
Lost in the ruins of my father,
Which made me think her murdered.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Ye gods! I now acknowledge you supreme:
Your power is mighty over our fond arts.
Silly projectors we ensnare ourselves!
Whilst we spread nets for others.
This brain has wrought all these sad plots,
Calantha, take your lord; who is as true,
And holy in his vows , as those blessed saints
He invoked.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: And yet Felicia wronged?

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: 'Twas I by whom she swelled, and not Ferrando,
As 'twas supposed.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: Supposed! she swore 'twas he.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Ursini, farewell; I'll hear the rest anon —

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: That aggravates my crime, who wrought her into
This false belief, for having long loved her,
Without return of mutual flames, and at length
Finding that the impediment was her fond
Dotage upon the prince; I determined,
Rather than not to be possessed of her,
To part with faith and loyalty, feigned all
My visits for him, courted her acceptation
Of his love, which I so darkly brought about
That she consenting to private meetings
As oft as she expected the prince,
I myself filled her arms. —

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: Then you conclude Ferrando innocent ▪

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: In act, or thought.

sp.speaker: Zis:
sp.l: Felicia! sister! your brother Frederico calls,
she's gone, cold, cold! and pale, and yet methinks
She smiles, look up, Felicia —

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: But how came it to pass she ne'er descried you?

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: For reasons I then gave her: all our meetings
Were in the night, and that i'th dark too, where I
Dissembled so the prince in voice and gesture. —

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: This agrees right with her relation: villain thou haste undone me.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: And myself too.

sp.speaker: Zisc.
sp.p: Death hangs upon her lids, 'tis eternal night with her. hoa, sister, stay, take me along with you; I'll follow you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Pernicious traitor.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Rage chokes my utterance: — give me your sword.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Our hearts and hands are yours:

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Our hearts and hands are yours:

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: I'll be an age in killing thee, dost tremble?
Thou lookest like one of those thin frozen ghosts,
That chattering lie on hills of thick-ribbed ice,
Come meet my fury.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Here, here's my heart.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: I: I'll dig it out,
And cast it to the hungry fiends.

sp.speaker: Zis:
sp.p: My strength decays, I reel and totter like a cracked reed that leans against the winds.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: Take your sword. —

sp.speaker: Urs:
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: Take it I say.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You do him too much honour.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: Managed with skill and strength, or thou affront'st
My honour, — faint-hearted! coward, I'll follow thee to hell.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Mercy heavens!

sp.speaker: Zis.
sp.p: Ho! Charon, more company, lie farther there jolt-head, what quarrelling you dogs? thy oar, thy oar ferryman: clap 'em o'th sconce with't, there, there.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: The gods are just.

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.p: You wore their cause upon your sword.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: 'Tis poor revenge this, can he not live again?
Start up from th'earth with life, and double strength?
Were't centupled I'd meet him: — but o my eyes!
Look here Valenzo: which is prince, which subject,
Which is my loved Ferrando? I see there is
No ceremonious state, no pomp in death;
They all lie level, all quiet, the bad as well
As the good, why should this traitor here
This devilish arch, arch-traitor lie as silent
As his lord? should he not stare, and foam,
Start up and howl, till he wakes all the dead?

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.p: Lady:

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.p: Her old passion returns again.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: — Roar, and curse heavens,
But they too have forgotten to punish sinners,
And reward virtue, here's an example on't;
We were both virtuous, and deserved not this
Bad usage; let me embrace thee: —
Cold as the earth he lies on, and as dull too:
Where is the soul, that busy flame that lent
Him life and motion? affected such vain pomp
And glorious noise: whither is't fled? poor liveless trunk,
It was unkindly done to leave thee thus,
A prey to worms and rottenness.

sp.speaker: Zis.
sp.l: Are you there fury, Megaera, Tisiphone, Allecto,
Howle, howl, furies, I'll lash you.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Kind death thou'rt welcome; I kiss thy dart.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: The Princess! she's slain, unlucky hand.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: Spite of our stars, and all rude opposition,
We are one in death: Valenzo see us interred,
Both in one tomb, that we may mingle ashes
And be securely lodged, you know our souls
Were one; our hearts were long united.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: A fatal union.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: Draw, draw the curtains there, my love and I
Must sleep; — uncivil I protest, put out the lights,
We shall sleep best i'th dark; pray don't disturb us,
You may fright him from mine arms, — but — I'll — hold — him — fast.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The ruined treasure of two kingdoms
In one heap.
sp.stage: Enter Charintha, Piero, Violetta, Florinda, Alphonso.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: In the bedchamber! this way!

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.p: Yes lady, the cry was full of horror.

sp.speaker: Viol:
sp.p: 'Twas the physician's potion this my lord.

sp.speaker: Flor:
sp.p: Done in revenge.

sp.speaker: Alph:
sp.p: Would 'thad been poison.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.p: Bless me! whence all these tragedies.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.p: Astonishment seizes me.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: The King:

sp.speaker: Calantha:
sp.p: Ursini dead. ha! whom have we here, Frederico,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes, and Felicia too.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: All slain; by what dire hand?

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.l: I'll tell you that within. —
Charintha is your Queen.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.p: May you be happy in her love.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.p: Remove the bodies, i'th morning we will take order for the state, and funeral rites.

lg.l: Of these; the lasting story of whose wrongs
Shall be all royal lover's evening songs.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: After these ruins, thus your poet stands,
Expecting his own destiny from your hands,
By them he lives or dies; if it should hap
That stead of a mild doom, applause or clap.
Meet with harsh whispers, or half stifled jeers,
Such unkind censure kills him; his sad muse
Unless you give her bay, has vowed to use
The cypress wreathes, her piety did allow
Those only to encircle her own brow:
New life and soul to his lost poesy;
His flame's but sickly yet, your breath no doubt
Will either blow't up higher, or quite out.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
